text: LONDON - Grief turned to anger as firefighters continued to battle one of London’s biggest fire disasters in recent memory and leaders faced questions about possible fire safety violations.Police say at least 12 people were killed as a rapidly-moving blaze raced through a 24-story apartment building in West London in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, trapping residents.The death toll was expected to rise as firefighters went floor by floor, dousing the remaining flames and searching for survivors and victims in the high-rise.Grenfell Tower contained an estimated 120 apartments and was home to as many as 600 people. The building is in an ethnically diverse, densely populated West London’s North Kensington area. Among those missing on Wednesday were a number of children.Witnesses said they heard screams for help as the fire stormed through the floors, trapping residents who could be seen from windows flashing their cell phone lights in hopes of being rescued. Witnesses said some residents held small children from windows while other people jumped from the lower stories of the building.?Watch video from the scene:Sorry, but your browser cannot support embedded video of this type, you can download this video to view it offline.Why did fire spread so quickly?

Turkey's former army chief was arrested on Friday over an alleged plot to topple the government of Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.General Ilker Basbug's lawyer said authorities have jailed his client, who is accused of leading a terrorist organization.A Turkish prosecutor called for the general to be taken into custody on Thursday after he was named as a suspect in an alleged Internet campaign aimed at destabilizing Erdogan's Islamic-based government.Turkish media reports said earlier this week that Basbug was called to answer questions in connection with the trial of current and former officers linked to the so-called secularist network, Ergenekon.Turkish authorities have detained more than 300 people including journalists, academics and politicians as part of a wide-reaching investigation into Ergenekon.The case has highlighted international concerns about press freedom in Turkey. Thursday, journalists Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik were among 13 defendants who appeared in court to begin their defense case against charges they are linked to Ergenekon.

A former North Korean spy has met with family members of a Japanese woman who was apparently abducted by the North's agents. Kim Hyun-hee - once sentenced to death for blowing up an airliner - says she may have information about the Japanese woman's fate.Former North Korean spy Kim Hyun-hee wiped tears from her eyes, Wednesday, as she spoke to the brother and son of a Japanese woman who disappeared decades ago.Kim told the relatives not to give up hope and that they will see the woman again. Kim Hyun-hee has not appeared in such a high-profile way since 1991 - when she spoke to the South Korean public about an act of terrorism she was convicted of committing, four years earlier. Kim says she placed a bomb on a Korean Airlines flight that exploded in midair, killing all 115 people on board. For that crime, she was sentenced to die, then given a South Korean presidential pardon.To fulfill her mission, Kim posed with another North Korean agent as a married Japanese couple. She says was able to speak and act as a Japanese person because she was taught for two years by Yaeko Taguchi - the woman whose family says she was abducted to North Korea in 1978.Wednesday's emotional meeting between Kim and two of Taguchi's male family members took place in Busan.

(WASHINGTON) — House Speaker Paul Ryan said Thursday he doesn’t want President Donald Trump working with Democrats to overhaul the nation’s health care system, declaring it’s not “productive.”“If we’re going to be having conversations with our colleagues across the aisle, I want those to be conversations that lead to results and solutions, and it just seems to me working with the Democrats to try to create a liberal wish list doesn’t do that,” Ryan told reporters.The Wisconsin Republican also said Congress should tackle the politically divisive issue of immigration next, “and the way to do that is to put a bipartisan bill on the floor, let it pass and then see where we can find common ground and come up with a consensus so we can get immigration reform done.”Trump has been signaling in recent days a willingness to work with Democrats, even as he sends a flurry of tweets criticizing the party over health care and other matters.Ryan also said Congress should tackle the politically divisive issue of immigration next. Ryan said he’d like to help “Dreamers,” young immigrants brought to the U.S. as children and living here illegally, but won’t tolerate special treatment for people in the country illegally.Trump wants to create a pathway to citizenship for up to 1.8 million people eligible for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. Conservatives are opposed to the idea and Democrats have been unwilling to negotiate further until Trump shows he can lead the GOP.“

A well-known opposition figure is claiming he is the new interim leader of the main opposition coalition as the ruling party heads toward elections expected later this year.Tanzania's main opposition coalition is divided about the party's presidential candidate for this year's elections, and an official with the main party says there is no need to form a coalition until after the vote.The leader of the opposition Tanzania Labour Party, Ibrahim Lipumba, announced Tuesday that he was taking over as interim chairman of the alliance. He says the opposition will not nominate a candidate until after the election.Lipumba told reporters he was aware of a challenge for the role of interim leader from John Magufuli of the ruling CCM party, "but this is not going to change anything."Magufuli has been the CCM candidate for the past three presidential elections. In the latest presidential election, Magufuli won nearly 95 percent of the vote in a poll that was denounced by international observers.The government has since taken measures to silence the opposition, with at least eight people arrested for alleged posts on social media deemed critical of Magufuli.Tanzania's main opposition party, Chadema, has said it will field its own candidate for the presidency this year.The country is expected to hold the parliamentary and local elections in October, followed by the presidential vote in November or December.

An Iranian diplomat has been arrested in the Austrian capital Vienna and charged with seeking to procure explosive and detonator components for a plot against opponents in France, according to prosecutors.An Iranian diplomat has been arrested in the Austrian capital Vienna and charged with seeking to procure explosive and detonator components for a plot against opponents in France, according to prosecutors.A joint investigation between French, Austrian and German intelligence agencies led to the arrest of Assadollah Assadi, a Vienna-based diplomat who was a point man in the alleged plot, Paris prosecutors said on Thursday.Assadi, now detained in Germany, had been ordered to leave the country by Iran on June 29 after the plot was foiled.French intelligence agents had already warned their German counterparts to be vigilant after receiving the same tip.German police have searched his house in the northern German city of Antwerp, which prosecutors believe was his operational base.“This investigation focuses on the activity of a terrorist network that wanted to carry out an attack in France on Austrian soil at the instigation of Iranian authorities,” said Francois Hollande, who was attending a European Council meeting in Brussels with German Chancellor Angela Merkel.“If he committed the actions, this person will be prosecuted and convicted. We want the law to take its course,” said Austrian Chancellor Christian Kern, who said Vienna was taking part in the investigation.Assadi, who worked at the Iranian diplomatic mission in Vienna, was “strongly suspected” of being one of the organisers of the alleged plot to attack the event in France.“

The Bush administration says it is not contemplating curtailing the current surge of U.S. forces in Iraq, as it prepares its first report on the surge due this week to an increasingly skeptical Congress. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.Both here and at the White House, officials steered reporters away from a New York Times story that says senior officials are discussing changing the Iraq strategy President Bush announced in January. White House spokesman Tony Snow put it this way."There is no intensifying discussion about reducing troops," said Tony Snow.At the Pentagon, spokesman Bryan Whitman acknowledged that Defense Secretary Robert Gates postponed a trip to Latin America in order to participate in policy meetings on Iraq this week. He said discussions are going on about what he called "the way ahead" in Iraq. And he reported that Secretary Gates participated in a national security team meeting early Monday morning, after meeting with the commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, Admiral William Fallon.But Whitman also noted that the latest security operation in Iraq is just three weeks old, and began as soon as all the extra forces President Bush ordered to Iraq had arrived."What this department is focused on is implementing the full capabilities that the surge forces are giving the commanders on the ground," said Bryan Whitman.Whitman dismissed comments by a growing number of Republican members of Congress, who have said the new Iraq strategy is not working and needs to be changed."None of those people seem to be our military commanders on the ground," he said.

The United States has been using drones in its war on terror across the globe, and has carried out thousands of drone attacks on the battlefields of the Middle East. These have not only been used to target terrorists in the region, but have resulted in an untold number of civilian casualties and the deaths of many children.Now, a study published by the New York Times Magazine claims these drone strikes, which have been conducted across Pakistan, are not effective militarily, and pose a moral hazard to the Pakistani government.The study claims that "drone strikes have killed an estimated 3,325 to 4,186 combatants and 487 to 881 civilians" from 2004 to 2012."By every traditional measure of military efficacy, drone strikes appear to be among the least effective of American war-fighting instruments in use today," write Steve Coll and Katherine Tiedemann.The study, titled Drone Wars: The Perils and Politics of US Counterterrorism Policy, claims that there is a "growing skepticism among Western and American experts" about the drone program, according to The Guardian, which first reported the research."We have done a terrible job of distinguishing terrorists from other fighters on the ground, creating a moral hazard for the Pakistani government that has yet to be addressed," the study's authors write.Pakistanis also express concern with U.S. drone strikes. In 2013, a poll conducted by the Pew Research Center found that Pakistanis were the most likely to believe the United States was mainly targeting civilians, according to The New York Times Magazine, which reported on the new study."The drones kill civilians because they cause damage, and it could be that the damage kills civilians," said Pakistan-based political scientist Huma Baqai, one of the authors of the study, who interviewed dozens of witnesses to drone strikes and interviewed key U.S. and Pakistani officials, in The Times Magazine.One Pakistani who lives near the Pakistan-Afghanistan border told The Times Magazine that he has been injured by a drone strike."It left me with a wound on my leg," said the man, who was only identified as Saifullah.

, and That's a Good ThingIn his May 25 Opinion column, "No, the coronavirus doesn't have a 'cure.' It doesn't need one," David Ignatius suggests that we should try to stop all infectious diseases before they spread. Yet it is precisely because we are unable to stop all viruses that they remain important tools in our war against other diseases. For thousands of years, humans have fought against infectious diseases by developing a variety of vaccines. These vaccines work well because viruses tend to evolve in ways that make them safe from the antibodies they generate. This is a process called "antigenic shift," which has allowed us to make vaccines for hundreds of deadly viruses.Mr. Ignatius's suggestion that we have no control over viral epidemics is simply wrong. In addition, this false suggestion may lead people to believe that we must be helpless in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. Yet even without a vaccine, we can slow transmission in both the short and long term. Mr. Ignatius's solution would be like trying to eliminate all military weapons because they are all dangerous.Daryl C.

The family of Basuki Tjahaya Purnama and his lawyers on Tuesday announced the recently defeated governor of Jakarta better known as "Ahok" had revoked the decision to appeal a two-year sentence for blasphemy handed down by the North Jakarta District Court.Ahok's wife, Veronica Tan, delivered the notice to the court Monday. She did not comment on the decision, which was filed less than an hour after Purnama's legal team filed paperwork for the appeal, according to local media.On Tuesday, she cried as she read a statement written by her husband."I know it's not easy for you to accept this fact, much less me," she said at a news conference, quoting her husband. "But I have learned to forgive and accept all this, for the good of the nation and the state."

The U.S. government on Thursday marked International Women's Day by recognizing 10 women who are fighting for human rights and equality. Presenting this year's International Women of Courage awards, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said championing women's equality is not only the right thing to do, it is the smart thing to do."Improving the lives of women improves the lives of their families, strengthens their communities and does create more opportunities for economic growth and prosperity," she said. "We know that investing in women's employment, health and education levels leads to a greater economic growth across a broad spectrum.?

, San Francisco"We all knew something terrible was going to happen to America," said John Van Meter, artistic director of San Francisco's Magic Theatre, who wrote the play in response to the 2016 presidential election.Van Meter, whose other works include "We Are Proud to Present a Presentation About the Herero of Namibia, Formerly Known as South West Africa, From the German Südwestafrika, Between the Years 1884-1915," thought it was necessary to prepare for the inauguration, but not for the reasons one might think."I started writing the play months before the election," Van Meter said. "It was never, 'Oh, what's going to happen? I have to write a play about this.' It was more like, 'I have to write a play about this because I love writing plays.'"Van Meter's latest play, "The American Dream," was written specifically for the Magic Theatre's upcoming production and is not intended to be a Trump-specific commentary."It's really about the dream and what people are willing to do to get to it," Van Meter said. "It doesn't specifically talk about Trump. It's more about this idea that in America we think we're this exceptional country and that anyone can become President. The person who's least qualified to be President is the person who becomes President."There's a person with great political experience, who has served as a Senator and Secretary of State, and then there's the person with no political experience, who's a real estate mogul with a reality television show. The people who voted for him and the people who hate him are both Americans."Van Meter will present "The American Dream," which stars Magic Theater alumnus John Griesemer, beginning Jan. 13, but not before presenting another one of his current theatrical works, "All About Us," which deals with the immigrant experience in the U.S. and is slated to begin performances Friday.Van Meter said "All About Us" had been planned before Trump's election victory and the cast is entirely Latino. "All About Us" was written in part about his family's own immigration to the U.S."We were looking for a show about the immigrant experience, because we thought that would be a good thing to do after an election," Van Meter said.

Pakistani rescue workers carry the dead body of a victim after a bomb explosion at a vegetable market in Peshawar on Jan. 31, 2012. Police say at least 13 people were killed in a suicide attack near Peshawar, the capital of restive northwestern Pakistan, in one of the bloodiest bombings to hit the country in recent years.At least 13 people were killed on Wednesday in a suicide attack on a vegetable market in Peshawar, the capital of restive northwestern Pakistan, in one of the bloodiest bombings to hit the country in recent years.In the past, suicide bomb attacks have been almost unheard of in this country of 160 million people. However, in recent months, militants have been behind a spate of incidents.An Afghan Taliban faction claimed responsibility for the suicide bombing in Peshawar, though no group has yet officially said it was behind an attack in the eastern city of Lahore last week that killed a popular provincial governor and at least 22 others.Police said that more than a dozen people were killed and more than 30 wounded by a bomber at the vegetable market in Peshawar, many of them women."The bomber was in an open vegetable stall when he blew himself up," a police source told Reuters. A witness at the scene said he saw a body with parts of its head missing.The attack took place at the vegetable market in the Shoba Bazaar area of Peshawar, which lies along the main route used by military supplies bound for NATO troops fighting the Taliban in Afghanistan.The main Taliban commander in the nearby tribal zone, Baitullah Mehsud, and at least eight members of his family were killed in a U.S. drone strike in August 2009.

BERLIN - An old-time propeller plane crashed near-vertically at high speed into a Swiss mountain, killing all 20 people on board, police said Sunday. The Junkers Ju-52 plane, operated by the Swiss company Ju-Air, went down Saturday on the Piz Segnas mountain above the Alpine resort of Flims, striking the mountain's western flank about 2,540 meters (8,330 feet) above sea level. The mountainous area in southeastern Switzerland is popular with hikers and skiers and includes a glacier. Police said Sunday they have now determined that all 20 people on board the plane, including its three crew members, died. Eleven men and nine women between the ages of 42 and 84 were killed. Most of the victims were Swiss but they also included a couple and their son from Austria. Photos released by Graubuenden canton (state) police showed the crumpled wreckage of the plane lying on the mountain, with only the upside-down tail more or less intact. Police said they are not aware of any distress call from the aircraft before it crashed. Daniel Knecht of the Swiss Transportation Safety Investigation Board said the plane appears to have hit the ground near-vertically and at high speed.

Washington, D.C., Feb. 16, 2010 - President Obama today announced that he intends to nominate Tom Delahanty II to the position of Executive Director of the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). Delahanty will join PEPFAR as it faces significant financial challenges, and has been criticized by some for failing to reach some of its ambitious goals. HIV/AIDS advocates say he has shown an ability to work with lawmakers and a dedication to reaching the most vulnerable populations around the world who stand to benefit from the HIV/AIDS programs.“Tom Delahanty has shown an incredible ability to work with Democrats and Republicans to reach important policy goals for communities living with HIV/AIDS in the United States and throughout the world,” said Paul Kawata, Policy Director at the AIDS Institute, one of three HIV/AIDS advocacy organizations that met today with Delahanty to make their comments on his nomination. “We look forward to working with him in this capacity and are pleased that this administration has selected him to lead this critical program.”Delahanty most recently served as Executive Director of the Office of National AIDS Policy at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, where he spearheaded the development and passage of the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), the single largest commitment of foreign assistance in history dedicated to fighting the global HIV/AIDS pandemic.“

Islam Times - U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov signalled their intention to try to improve relations between their countries, which are at post-Cold War lows, as they held their first talks Thursday evening in Iceland.Lavrov arrived in the Icelandic capital of Reykjavik for talks after a meeting with his Turkish counterpart in Turkey. Blinken, who is on a tour of Europe, arrived later.“When it comes to Russia our goal is a stable, predictable relationship," Blinken said as he met his Russian counterpart at the Harpa Concert Hall, overlooking the city. “We think that’s good for our people, good for Russian people and indeed good for the world.”Lavrov said he believed the meeting would be “quite constructive” and that there was much to discuss, including cooperation in Afghanistan and the Iran nuclear issue as well as normalisation of ties.Both men said they hoped for more stable and predictable relations between Washington and Moscow. Blinken said earlier this week the main focus of the talks would be on arms control treaties between the two countries.Blinken and Lavrov last met in January 2020 in Berlin.

ATHENS - Europe's refugee crisis is posing risks for the Greek economy and the country needs substantial help to deal with the migratory flows, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said on Thursday."The refugee crisis creates significant problems for the Greek economy and growth," OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria told reporters after meeting Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Athens."Greece needs to receive substantial support to deal with this new challenge. No single country can address this challenge on its own," he said in comments translated into Greek.Gurria projected zero growth for the Greek economy this year and a 1.9 to 2 percent GDP increase in 2017.

French singer Johnny Hallyday, who is awaiting trial on charges of tax fraud, was transferred last Friday to a prison cell, where he will remain until September 21 when his trial begins.The prosecutor says there is no evidence to suggest that Mr. Hallyday, known as French "Johnny" Cash, did anything wrong, adding that his tax troubles are simply due to mistakes by his accountants.A French newspaper, "L'Express", reports that Mr. Hallyday had three French-style country houses built in the French Alps under a false name, and had the work done by two companies in which he was a partner. Prosecutors say Mr. Hallyday, who is accused of fraud totaling nearly $16 million, also used a web of front companies to hide real estate and other assets.Mr. Hallyday's lawyer, Jacques Toubon, says that his client "never lied about anything." Mr.

Thousands of opposition supporters rallied in Taiwan today to protest President Chen Shui-bian's independence-leaning policies which are increasingly provoking China. Protestors are concerned Mr. Chen is spending more time stirring up trouble with China than solving problems at home.Tens of thousands of demonstrators chanted slogans in Taipei Sunday criticizing President Chen Shui-bian recent moves that have antagonized China.In the last several months, Mr. Chen has sparked tensions with Beijing when he suspended a commission responsible for reunification with China. He also scrapped reunification guidelines and proposed amending the constitution to change the island's name from "Republic of China" to "Taiwan."China sees these actions as moving dangerously close to Taiwan formally declaring independence - something Beijing has vowed to stop by force if necessary. While the democratic island has been self-ruled since 1949 - the communist mainland considers it a renegade province.China's opposition Kuomintang organized Sunday's rally, calling on the Chen government to stop provoking China and focus on domestic issues.Kuomintang chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, spoke to crowds of supporters.Ma says there are many problems Taiwan needs to address - including corruption and the economy. He says if Taiwan gets its priorities wrong there will be a huge price to pay.Ma, who is the mayor of Taipei and considered a presidential favorite in Taiwan's 2008 elections, will be in the United States this week.He is to discuss a stalled U.S. weapons sale.

Israeli authorities have approved 200 new homes in a Jewish area of East Jerusalem, a move sure to anger Palestinians as tensions between the two sides continue to grow.A government spokeswoman said officials approved the houses Wednesday for the Ramot area on the northern edge of Jerusalem.There was no immediate comment from Palestinian officials. But U.S. State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said the United States was deeply concerned. She said new Jewish settlement construction could worsen a difficult situation and would not contribute to efforts to reduce tensions.Psaki also condemned an arson attack on a mosque in the West Bank on Wednesday, apparently carried out by Israeli extremists. She said hateful actions against a place of worship are never justified.Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas during a visit to Jordan on Thursday.Much of the recent violence in Israel has stemmed from the dispute over the Temple Mount, a holy site that Muslims call the al-Aqsa mosque. It is revered by Muslims and Jews.The long-simmering dispute over the site worsened this month when Israeli police shot dead a Palestinian gunman who had seriously wounded a U.S.-born rabbi. The rabbi had been part of a conference on expanding the rights of Jews to worship at the site.Also Wednesday, Israel's foreign ministry said it had no intention of cooperating with a U.N.

May 21, 2012 at 4:08 AM (PT)It was a mixed session for the major indices TUESDAY (5/22) as they continue to track each other in the same trading range they've been stuck in since FRIDAY (5/18). The NASDAQ fell over seven and a half points to close at 2558 while the SPOT S&P 500 was off four and a half to close at 1298. The Dow dropped 39 points, and is currently at 12961. Trading was quiet as a holiday in the U.K. caused many European markets to be closed.WEDNESDAY is the last day of Q1 for companies and also marks the end of another record-breaking year for the U.S. markets. This week, the MUTUAL FUND ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA is predicting that the S&P 500 will hit 1450 in 2012, but if it closes under 1399 it will be the worst first quarter for the S&P since the recession in 2009. MFS says that the global economic slowdown will continue, but predicts a modest rally during the summer.A FEDERAL RESERVE FOCUSED ADMINSTRATION (FRFAA) study of over 40 years of past FED communications says it looks like the current FED Chairman will follow in his two predecessors' footsteps by making a public statement about monetary policy when the FED announces its interest rate decision on THURSDAY (5/24). The study looked at what FED Chmn. JIM BLIMKIN said in his opening statement and press conference as well as the first FOMC meeting. It found that both FED Chmn. GEORGE MEYER and CHAIRMAN BERNANKE spoke about economic growth, the labor market and the housing market, and both expressed concerns about inflationary pressures. The report notes that neither mentioned the dollar or interest rates.

Ethiopia's football team has reached the group stage of the 2014 World Cup qualifiers with a comfortable victory over neighboring Somalia. But, for the thousands of Somalis packed into a corner of Addis Ababa stadium, a 5-0 drubbing felt like a victory.As Somalia's fans trooped out of the stands following Wednesday's game, you might have thought they had won. Twenty-five-year-old Mohamed Hussein, a Somali refugee from Mogadishu, was ecstatic.?I'm so happy, I want to thank the players, and I want to thank the people of Somalia today who stay in Addis Ababa who support our team," said Hussein.A valiant Somali side held Ethiopia to a scoreless draw in the first leg of this home and away match, held Saturday in Djibouti. In this return leg in Addis Ababa, the Ocean Stars trailed by only 1-0 at the one hour mark, before the superior Ethiopian side unleashed a torrent of goals.The team for war-torn Somalia faces huge disadvantages in international competition, among them the lack of a home field. Mogadishu Stadium has not been used for sporting events in recent years. Instead, it was used by Islamist militant group al-Shabab for floggings and executions.Somali refugee Hamdi Wardhere called the final score ?great? considering the difficulties his country faces."I'm very delighted how I see my team and how they played, so I'm very happy really," said Wardhere.

Ethiopia’s prime minister, Dr. Abiy Ahmed, announced this week that the country is inviting businesses from all around the world to explore opportunities in different sectors. The message was delivered through the State of the Nation Address (SONA) on Tuesday, Feb. 26, 2019.In his speech, PM Ahmed highlighted the recent economic and political reforms the country has undergone over the past year. He also emphasized how those changes and the nation’s strategic location make Ethiopia an ideal investment destination for the world.“Ethiopia is the second-most populous nation in Africa, the second most populous country in the Horn of Africa, and the most populous nation in East Africa, with one of the world’s fastest growing economies,” the PM said.“Ethiopia is an ideal investment destination. We are inviting businesses from all around the world to explore the business opportunities that exist in the country.”The nation’s economic reforms include liberalizing the importation of goods, increasing the productivity of the economy by boosting manufacturing and improving productivity of the agriculture sector, expanding the tourism sector, opening up and reforming the financial sector, improving infrastructure and supporting the development of small and medium enterprises, among others.The nation’s leadership, which is currently working to reform laws to make it easier for investors to do business in Ethiopia, also wants to attract foreign direct investments as well as investments from the large Ethiopian Diaspora.The nation is also planning to establish Special Economic Zones (SEZs) in key areas such as energy and manufacturing. Ethiopia is the largest power exporter in the Horn of Africa and has been attracting new investments in power generation. It is also developing large industries and SEZs around the country, including a textile and apparel SEZ in Hawassa, for example.Ethiopia has also opened up the telecom sector over the past few years and is currently experiencing rapid growth in the number of mobile users.The nation is also working with the World Bank and other international partners to support its plans to expand trade in coffee, spices and other commodities by strengthening the nation’s market infrastructure and the quality of its products.This year Ethiopia will also hold the 2019 Conference on African Development (AfDA), the premier event on African economic development.

Somalia's interim Prime Minister Ali Mohamed Gedi says his secular government troops and their Ethiopian allies are firmly in control of the capital, Mogadishu, one day after the once-powerful Islamists hastily abandoned the city. VOA Correspondent Alisha Ryu has details from our East Africa Bureau in Nairobi.In a telephone interview with VOA shortly before he entered the capital, Prime Minister Gedi says Somali government troops are now headquartered in the former U.S. Embassy compound in western Mogadishu and assessing the security situation.The interim leader acknowledges that the first priority for his government is to restore stability in the capital. He says he has been given assurances by clan elders in Mogadishu that they would switch support of the Islamists to the interim government and help disarm and re-train hundreds of Islamist militiamen, who found themselves without a job Thursday after the sudden collapse of the Islamist movement."They are ready to hand over weapons to the government and also the militias to be trained in camps. So, this is a victory for the Somali people in the country and in particular, the capital city of Mogadishu," he said.Many Islamist fighters shed their uniforms and sought advice from clan leaders about what to do next.

A leader at one of Virginia's largest mosques has resigned after the imam there made comments in support of female genital mutilation.Imam Johari Abdul-Malik, who was director of outreach at the Dar Al-Hijrah mosque in Falls Church, posted his resignation Friday on his website.Abdul-Malik says he's leaving after "many reprehensible statements" by Dar Al-Hijrah's senior imam, Shaker Elsayed, including his recent comments on genital mutilation.In a recorded lecture, Elsayed described the practice as a way to avoid "hyper-sexuality" and "the honorable thing to do if needed."Dar Al-Hijrah's board denounced Elsayed's comments Monday. Two days later, it placed him on administrative leave.FILE - Imam Shaker Elsayed delivers the sermon at prayers services at the Dar al-Hijra mosque in Falls Church, Va., June 15, 2005.In the lecture, Elsayed says that the practice, also known as female circumcision, has received a bad name because poorly trained surgeons are too aggressive in the procedure. He said the surgery is properly carried out with a minimalist approach "so that she is not hyper-sexually active. This is the purpose."Elsayed later issued a clarification through the mosque's website saying that "Islam would never support anything that harms anybody's well-being" and that he should have avoided his comments on hyper-sexuality."I hereby take it back. And I do apologize to all those who are offended by it," Elsayed wrote.Abdul-Malik says in his resignation that the board's actions against Elsayed are insufficient."Ultimately, The Board of Dar Al-Hijrah Islamic Center is responsible for the direction of the community and its leadership.

North Korea has fired another ballistic missile, days after the United States imposed new sanctions on the reclusive state.South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff said the missile flew 800 kilometers before crashing off the North's eastern coast early Friday. The South said it tracked the projectile and was monitoring the situation.A U.S. defense official says the U.S. tracked the launch of two ballistic missiles from North Korea. The official said neither was assessed to be a threat to the U.S. or its allies, and noted that the launches are a violation of multiple U.N. Security Council resolutions.President Barack Obama signed an executive order imposing new sanctions Wednesday in response to the authoritarian regime's latest nuclear and ballistic missile tests.Earlier this week, Pyongyang's state media said North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had ordered tests of a nuclear warhead and ballistic missiles capable of carrying warheads.Military tensions have been soaring on the divided Korean Peninsula since the North carried out its fourth nuclear test on January 6, followed a month later by a long-range rocket launch that was widely seen as a disguised ballistic missile test.The North says it needs nuclear weapons to cope with what it calls U.S. military threats.After the latest firing, the United States called on North Korea to refrain from actions that raise tensions in the region.

New warnings of famine and food shortages have been sounded for parts of the Horn of Africa.The Famine Early Warning Systems Network says more than one-million people in south and southeast Ethiopia face "extreme food insecurity" due to the failure of normal late-year rains.The U.S.-funded group says pre-famine conditions have emerged in several districts, including Afder, Liban and Gode).The group says two million people need humanitarian aid in Somalia, mostly in the south, where the poor rainfall has led to widespread crop failure.

New Zealand police said there were multiple fatalities after a mass shooting at two mosques in Christchurch, a city of about 375,000 located on the nation’s South Island.Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said the shootings have led to “one of New Zealand’s darkest days.”What is the history of Christchurch, New Zealand?The planned settlement of Christchurch was founded in 1850 by a company financed by the Church of England.?4,545,627, as of July 2018, according to the CIA: The World Factbook.The estimated number of guns (both licit and illicit) held by civilians in New Zealand was estimated to be more than 1.2 million in 2017, according to GunPolicy.org.New Zealand has had few mass shooting deaths. One of the deadliest cases involved David Gray who in November 1990 went on a shooting spree in the small town of Aramoana, located about 360 kilometers south of Christchurch.

The full-scale Orion crew vehicle is designed to carry four astronauts in a re-entry capsule-like structure at up to 20,000 feet for periods of up to two hours at a time.A massive NASA rocket designed to carry astronauts on deep space exploration adventures blasted off Saturday to test components that will someday carry humans on missions to the moon and Mars.The 8 minute, 20 second test flight launched the Orion spacecraft atop the agency's super-heavy-lift rocket, called the Space Launch System (SLS). NASA plans to use the SLS to take astronauts to an asteroid as part of its future planetary defense program, and eventually to Mars.Orion is the agency's primary crew vehicle for its planned return to the moon, which is expected to happen in the mid-2020s. However, Orion is not a capsule like the Mercury, Gemini or Apollo vehicles of yore. The capsule measures 16.5 feet wide (5 meters), and its crew capsule measures 12.4 feet (3.8 m) in diameter. The craft is expected to carry four astronauts at a time on its first moon mission. [The Orion Spaceship: NASA's Future Moon-Orbiter (Infographic)]Orion blasted off from pad 37B at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla., at 7:05 a.m. EST (1105 GMT) Saturday. The launch was NASA's first from Florida since the space shuttle retired in 2011. The rocket that lifted Orion into space will also launch astronauts on future missions."We're not here today to mark the end of the Space Shuttle program, we're here today to mark the beginning of a new era of exploration," Mike Sarafin, the launch vehicle project manager at NASA's Kennedy Space Center, said during a Friday briefing.The test flight Saturday was designed to verify how Orion's performance and thermal protection system would perform when the spacecraft re-enters Earth's atmosphere after reaching deep space."

Article excerptCambodia's return to the international lending fold after its debt-relief programme expires next year has become highly contentious, as international donors debate whether to resume funding for the country's economic recovery.Many Western governments are concerned that Cambodia's government is seeking to return to power in elections due to be held by 2007, undermining political freedoms.A key concern is that the Cambodian government is seeking to gain economic leverage in the lead-up to the vote by re-writing the country's constitution to create a strong presidency.The US is now pushing back against the resumption of World Bank lending to Cambodia, claiming that its aid is being misused, in particular to prop up the royal family. Cambodia's leaders accuse the US of double standards, however, because the country has granted loans to other countries - including Egypt and Iraq - with questionable human rights records.On Thursday, Cambodia's government took a further step to distance itself from its Western creditors. Phnom Penh announced it was cancelling an aid deal with the UK that had promised to pay £15m to Cambodia's Red Cross.The Red Cross was to get two-thirds of the money but the rest was to be used to fund social programmes. Cambodia's National Assembly last week passed a law making the national government - rather than the NGOs - the legal owner of the country's NGOs, and the government said it was cancelling the deal because it feared a repeat of the 1999 collapse of the Cambodian Development Bank, when Western donors suspended aid to the country.In Washington, Cambodia's foreign minister, Hor Namhong, said he had little fear about the country's ability to survive the loss of Western aid. "We will look to China, South Korea and other Asian countries," Mr Namhong told The Financial Times. He denied that Cambodia was seeking to re-write its constitution ahead of the elections as a way to give itself greater political influence. "The government is not interested in maintaining its position. We are interested in strengthening democracy," he said.

The U.S. space agency NASA has released the first three dimensional pictures of the sun. It says the new view will greatly help scientists understand solar storms that can disrupt communications and power systems on Earth. VOA's David McAlary reports.The new 3-D images came from twin NASA spacecraft named STEREO, launched last October. They are orbiting the sun, one slightly ahead of Earth and the other slightly behind, gradually separating from each other until they are 500,000 kilometers apart. The separation provides a three dimensional view of the sun, just as the offset in our eyes gives us depth perception.Until the advent of this identical pair of observatories, images from Earth telescopes or orbiting solar telescopes were two dimensional. NASA solar scientist Madhulika Guhathakurta says the three dimensional images will help scientists determine where matter and energy flow in the sun's atmosphere much more precisely."We have to move away from the traditional sun-Earth line to view the sun from around, from over the poles, from under the poles to really get a deeper understanding of what is inside the sun, what is coming out of its surface, how is it affecting the entire solar system that we live in," said Madhulika Guhathakurta.The main STEREO project scientist, Michael Kaiser, says the satellites' depth perception will help improve space weather forecasts.Of particular concern are powerful eruptions of billions of tons of electrically charged gas that smash into Earth's magnetic field at millions of kilometers per hour.

Getachew Engida spoke in an interview Thursday about his work as deputy director general of the large U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, his views on the growth and development of societies around the world and his career path that lead him to UNESCO.“I wanted to do things that go beyond the financial and other profit goals,” Getachew said, “to explore causes that are not necessarily for profit-making but are good for the betterment of the society." He spoke with Alula Kebede, host of Cultural MosaicThe deputy director previously served for six years as comptroller of the Paris-based agency with oversight of a half-billion dollar annual budget.

WASHINGTON - The United States urged all Venezuelan political parties on Monday to follow up on the country's elections with a dialogue to deal with the country's economic and social challenges, saying Washington is ready to support such an effort.U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry congratulated Venezuelans on Sunday's legislative elections, in which the ruling Socialists lost their majority in the National Asseembly.The United States has long had an acrimonious relationship with Venezuela, which under President Nicolas Maduro and President Hugo Chavez before him has been a vocal critic of Washington.In a written statement, Kerry said the vote showed Venezuelans' "overwhelming desire" for a change in the direction of the country, and urged authorities "to continue to tabulate and publish voting results in a timely and transparent fashion."Sunday's victory for the opposition Democratic Unity coalition punished Maduro's government for deep economic and social crisis in the oil-producing country. It was the first time in 16 years that the "Chavismo" movement, named for former President Chavez, lost its majority in the 167-member assembly."

MANILA - The Philippines is one of the world’s most vulnerable countries when it comes to disasters and weather-related events. And this week it is hosting a three-day intensive seminar to help develop “climate leaders” who will be tasked to call attention to the impacts of climate change and what action can be taken.Climate reality From 1994 to 2013, the Philippines had 328 major weather events making it the worst-off country, according to data presented by former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, now the chairman of the Washington-based Climate Reality Project. Second on the list was Bangladesh, with 228 events.Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore addresses participants during a three-day climate change training and workshop on how best to address the effects of global climate change on March 14, 2016 in suburban Pasay city, south of Manila, Philippines.Gore’s presentation in Manila made the connection between rising earth temperatures, powerful storms, extreme heat, more prolonged drought and their impact on food supplies, public health and political stability.“I am constantly challenged in my own heart to realize the magnitude of these biblical changes that are going on right now,” he said.“ And we are the people alive in this day and time that have a responsibility to recognize it and then to act.”

in WashingtonWASHINGTON, DC — Indigenous activists from around the globe are in Washington, DC this week, protesting the EU-India free trade agreement. The activists, joined by several from the U.S. Congress, held a news conference outside the European Union headquarters on Tuesday. They warned that the agreement will threaten the health and environmental protection efforts of hundreds of Indian tribes, in addition to harming global efforts to combat climate change. "The EU-India free trade agreement is a huge step backward for our planet. Climate change will be a devastating force on Indigenous communities, which are the frontline defense against the coming extinction of the planet's biodiversity," said Faith Gemmill of Diné CARE. Gemmill, along with the rest of the activists, called on negotiators of the free trade agreement to meet with the Indigenous communities they are negatively impacting. "The EU must hear our plea to cancel this devastating agreement and take action," Gemmill said. "They must meet with Indigenous peoples impacted by this treaty and listen to our voices." The Indigenous communities who will be most affected by the agreement are in the European Union's home region, the bloc's largest export market and the world's third largest emitter of greenhouse gases. "The Indian tribes who fought to protect the earth and climate are on the front lines," said Kertu Kertu of Indigenous Environmental Network. "Our people are saying it's time to stop the bleeding, stop the extinction. The EU must stand on the right side of history, cancel this agreement, and support Indigenous rights and sovereignty." The Indigenous activists, as well as U.S. members of Congress, say they are determined to stop the agreement, not only in the U.S. Congress but also at the World Trade Organization. On Tuesday, a resolution from Rep. Ro Khanna to stop the agreement passed the House.

British Prime Minister Theresa May says she will step down before the country's next election scheduled for 2022. She was expected to offer to step aside early at a meeting with her cabinet of top ministers Friday.May was under pressure to step down following her failure to deliver an exit from the European Union two months after Britain voted to leave in 2016. May said it was her intention to remain in office but that she would step down before the next election."I know you want a new approach. I am prepared to leave this job earlier than I intended in order to do what is right for our country and our party," May told the Conservative Party lawmakers.She urged her cabinet to "come together" around a new leader as soon as possible.Theresa May has served as prime minister since July 2016. A long-standing supporter of the Remain camp in the Brexit debate, her failure to deliver Brexit has prompted speculation that she would be replaced sooner rather than later.The opposition Labour Party says it would back a second Brexit referendum if there was no prospect of securing a withdrawal from the EU via other means.May has agreed to meet her rival Boris Johnson — who is among those vying to replace her — for "constructive" talks over her Brexit deal. May lost a vote on her Brexit deal in parliament on Tuesday, leaving Britain and the EU with no clear path out of the crisis.

Thousands of people, many of them supporters of President-elect Donald Trump, will fill Washington, DC’s Freedom Plaza for a rally on Thursday in support of Trump’s call to “drain the swamp” in Washington, DC and protest President Barack Obama’s last-minute rules that would delay the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines.The rally will also be used as an opportunity to protest President Obama’s controversial executive actions on illegal immigration.The event is organized by the same people who organized the March for Trump in November, which drew more than 20,000 people to the National Mall.The rally is scheduled to begin at 12 p.m. ET at the Freedom Plaza and conclude with a march to the U.S. Capitol Building.The rally is also expected to include a diverse group of speakers that include Rep. Steve King (R-IA), Rep. Raul Labrador (R-ID), Sebastian Gorka, Donald Trump Jr., Roger Stone, Jack Posobiec, and more.Trump’s inauguration ceremony is scheduled to begin at 11:00 a.m. ET.

Somali women protest against Al-Shabab in Mogadishu. At the end of the protest, the protesters had a mock beheading, in which they symbolically killed Al-Shabab chief Ahmed Abdi Godane, with the head of a woman lying on the ground. The protest was sparked after Islamist militants executed four women on the accusation that they had practiced witchcraft.At least one woman was stoned to death in central Somalia this week after being convicted of witchcraft, according to a Somali rights activist.The stoning happened in Dangorod village in the Lower Shabelle region, near the Ethiopian border."We have confirmed that one woman was killed by a group of people in Dangorod," said Mohamed Abdikarin, the founder of Somali human rights group Galkayo Education Center.

WASHINGTON (AP) -Thursday, February 14, 2019 at 3:54 pm |Rep. Ed Royce, R-Calif., (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)U.S. lawmakers reacted with outrage Thursday to Iran’s choice of a hard-line diplomat as its ambassador to the United Nations, saying it underscores the need to extend sanctions against the country to make it more difficult to conduct diplomacy.House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel, D-N.Y., called it “a cynical and perverse choice” that makes it “that much harder for Iran to lead by example” as it advocates “regime change” in other countries.Sen. James Risch, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Iran’s selection of Mohammad Javad Zarif “undermines the international community’s desire to engage with Iran.” He said extending U.N. sanctions would send “a powerful signal” to Iran that its current policies are not acceptable.President Donald Trump pulled the U.S. out of the Iran nuclear deal last year and reimposed sanctions that were eased under the 2015 accord.“The supreme leader and president chose to send a message to the world through this extremist choice: Iran is open for business, but only if you agree to do business with the supreme leader and his regime,” Engel said. “And if you don’t, Iran will punish you.”On Wednesday, a committee controlled by Iran’s parliament approved Zarif’s appointment. He has been foreign minister since 2013 under the administration of moderate President Hassan Rouhani, who handily won re-election to a second term last week. Rouhani’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, is considered a moderate within Iran’s clerically overseen political system.Since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, the U.S. and its allies have viewed Iran with suspicion, regarding its nuclear and ballistic missile programs, involvement in regional conflicts and support for militant groups.Zarif met last week with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who was in Bangkok.

The Pentagon says an Iranian operative captured in Iraq on Thursday and accused of helping Iraqi insurgents was acting under orders from the elite Quds Force. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.The U.S. military command in Iraq says the man was arrested in Sulimaniyah Province in the northeast along the Iranian border. The command says the unidentified man is an officer of the Quds Force, an elite unit of Iran's Revolutionary Guards Corps. It says he was involved in transporting special, high-technology roadside bombs that have the power to pierce the armor of U.S. military vehicles. A U.S. military statement says there are indications from intelligence agencies that the man was also involved in training foreign fighters and smuggling them into Iraq.About six other alleged Quds force members have been detained in Iraq on similar charges, but U.S. officials have said they are not sure whether the men are operating under orders from the highest levels of the Iranian government.Still, Pentagon Press Secretary Geoff Morrell said Thursday it appears this latest detainee was not operating on his own."The Quds Force is a tightly controlled paramilitary force for the government of Iran," he said. "So I think it seems to us as though, indeed, he's not operating as a Lone Ranger in Iraq, but he has been presumably ordered to be there."

A typical math problem for an American middle school student might be to calculate the sales tax on a dozen baseball caps. At an after-school program called the Berkeley Math Circle, a typical problem is more? advanced. As she writes the hyperbolic cosine formula on the blackboard, circle director Zvezda Stankova asks the four dozen or so teens in the room to use it in a differential equation to describe the arc of a wire, hanging between two poles.It's no problem for 12-year-old Bobby Veres, who says Math Circle teens can handle this. He points out, "It's very prestigious. Most of the top math kids from around the Bay area come here. I like the chance that we get to learn extra math that isn't available in schools, and we get to make friends."They also get to hear from some top mathematicians and theorists, like astrophysicist Cliff Stoll. Stankova calls him the epitome of what you would think of an internationally renown scientist: "Absent-minded, yet very animated. Very sharp and very enthusiastic." And very demonstrative. Stoll is jumping high, spreading his arms wide, then running forward until he's nose to nose with the Math Circle students - all this to show the three dimensions of our universe: height, width and depth. With Stoll in command, the Math Circle takes a wild ride from our 3-D universe to an imaginary world of two dimensions, that's limited to only width and height. "Can I tie a knot in a string that's in a two-dimensional universe?" he asks, prompting a chorus of "No!" When one student says "yes," Stoll challenges him to prove it.
