SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA - The U.S. military faces a fresh challenge in its coronavirus fight as fears grow that thousands of troops could be forced to take unpaid leave this summer.Some 4,000 service members in South Korea are currently on furlough amid the global pandemic. The furloughs are supposed to last for just 60 days, or until May 5, but they could go on much longer if the coronavirus threat persists."We hope we do not have to extend the furlough past May 5, but as you know that's up to the secretary of defense, who is constantly reevaluating the coronavirus situation here," Colonel Chad Carroll, commander of the U.S. Army Garrison Daegu, told reporters.It is an anxious time in South Korea's Daegu, where more than 5,000 troops are stationed, and where most of South Korea's coronavirus cases were reported early on in the outbreak. The base now has more than 250 coronavirus cases.One of those patients is Sgt. Johnathan Roper. He caught the virus while off-duty and is now isolated in a small single room in a local hospital in South Korea. He is worried about his own health and also his family's financial well-being."At the end of the day, we're human. That's the first thing. I'm a father of four. I need to support my family," Roper told VOA.He says he has not received any furlough paperwork, so has no way of knowing how long he will be out of work. If furloughs continue beyond May 5, U.S. military families in South Korea will face financial hardship.FILE - U.S. soldiers at Camp Carroll, in Uijeongbu, South Korea, April 6, 2020.The Pentagon is now studying different scenarios in case furloughs are extended.One plan calls for no furloughs while another would force nearly 8,000 U.S. troops on furlough in South Korea to take eight days of leave each month.

Participants at the Cannes Film Festival will be given fliers warning "Proper Behavior Required" as part of an anti-sexual harassment campaign at the May 8-19 event.The top women's rights official for the French government announced Friday that she reached a deal with Cannes organizers for the campaign.

Three days of mourning were declared Tuesday in the Central African Republic (CAR) after the discovery of mass graves containing the bodies of at least 160 people who had been massacred in the north of the country, according to officials and UN peacekeepers.The three days of mourning will begin at midday Wednesday.“The massacres and murders of civilians are acts that shock, but they must unite us and lead us to act,” said President Francois Bozize.The bodies were discovered after a new anti-Balaka Christian militia called on other factions to join it in a military operation to capture the town of Bossembele, on the edge of the Muslim enclave of Bossangoa.A convoy of trucks and 4×4 vehicles were seen heading towards Bossangoa. A United Nations (UN) official in the town said several hundred fighters were involved in the military operation.The official, who asked not to be named, told Reuters: “They [the fighters] came in and attacked a village called Djakoa… They also attacked the neighboring village called Baga.”The UN official said that Bossembele was in the hands of anti-balaka.

CAPITOL HILL - Testifying before a Senate panel, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday declined to divulge details of President Donald Trump's private meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki last week, but declared the United States does not recognize Russia's 2014 annexation of Crimea."Presidents are entitled to have private meetings. … I think it was more than appropriate that President Trump meet with Vladimir Putin," Pompeo said in the first Capitol Hill appearance by a member of Trump's national security team since the Helsinki summit, at which the president questioned U.S. intelligence on Russian election meddling.FILE - U.S. President Donald Trump and Russia's President Vladimir Putin shake hands after their joint news conference in the Presidential Palace in Helsinki, Finland, July 16, 2018.Trump later sought to clarify his position on Russian interference. Pompeo told lawmakers the president was absolutely clear on Russia's actions in the 2016 U.S. presidential election."He [Trump] has a complete and proper understanding of what happened. I know — I briefed him on it for over a year," the secretary of state and former CIA director said after listing steps the administration had taken to counter Russia, from imposing sanctions to sending military aid to Ukraine."The United States does not and will not recognize the Kremlin's purported annexation of Crimea," Pompeo stressed, adding that economic sanctions against Moscow would remain "until Ukraine's territorial integrity is restored."Moments earlier, the White House announced that a planned second Trump-Putin summit in the United States would not occur until 2019.

Nairobi — Kenya's lawmakers want the Ministry of Public Health to take steps to stop the excessive use of alcohol, which they blame for the deaths and injuries resulting from road accidents, domestic violence and other criminal activities.Members of Parliament's Public Health Committee issued a statement Monday on the rising use of alcohol in Kenya. Committee chairman Mark Nyamita says alcohol abuse is a national catastrophe that must be curtailed.He says there has been a general decline in the population's health and a rise in diseases related to alcohol abuse.Nyamita adds that the ministry has the power to put in place programs aimed at stopping alcohol abuse."We want the ministry to come up with a special plan to address this menace. This can be done through public campaigns as well as educating the youth on the negative effects of alcohol abuse," said Nyamita.Kenya has over the past year recorded several road fatalities caused by drink driving.The country also has rising cases of alcohol abuse among youths.According to the 2016 Kenya National Alcohol Policy, 27.5% of the population aged 15 to 19 years is affected by harmful use of alcohol, resulting in social and health problems.That survey also found the use of alcohol among those aged 15 to 34 years was at 28.8%, up from 22.2% in 2010.The national policy calls for the introduction of measures aimed at preventing the sale of alcoholic beverages to persons below 18 years, and reducing the frequency of alcohol advertisements.

TAIPEI - A tiny group of islands in the East China Sea has shaped up as a flashpoint between Beijing and Tokyo. But smaller and diplomatically isolated Taiwan also claims the disputed Senkaku archipelago, which it calls the Diaoyutai. In Taipei, authorities have shied away from confrontation, while seeking to play a larger role in resolving the conflict. On Tuesday, Taiwanese officials urged Japan and China to back down from a conflict about the Senkaku islets, some 220 kilometers from Taiwan.Taiwan wants Japan to resume talks, after 16 earlier rounds, on fishing rights in waters near the uninhabited islets. Taiwan also asked the other claimants to consider Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou’s proposal for setting aside their territorial disputes to explore jointly for resources. Foreign Minister Timothy Yang told a news conference in Taipei that he is worried that the conflict will spiral. He says it is easy to escalate a conflict and harder to make peace. But Yang calls Taiwan a peacemaker for the international community and says that, in face of the East China Sea developments, the president has formulated a peace initiative. He adds that Ma is urging all sides to restrain themselves, set aside disputes, solve conflicts in a peaceful way and develop East China Sea resources together. The minister’s words reflect what analysts call the government’s underlying motives for seeking a broader role in the dispute. When President Ma took office in 2008, he said that despite diplomatic isolation Taiwan would try for more informal participation in international affairs.

Thousands of Parisians frustrated by continuous traffic jams and horrible commuting problems marched through the French capital Sunday, demanding an end to a nationwide rail workers' strike now entering its sixth day Monday.Many of the demonstrators said subway and commuter-train workers should return to work because they already enjoy privileges held by only a few other workers in France.Rail unions told their members to stay off the job today, but agreed to hold talks with managers of the state-run rail company on Wednesday.

MOSCOW — One of Russia’s richest women, the billionaire co-owner of the Bank of Cyprus, died in a small plane crash near Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, as her country prepared to mark the centennial of the Bolshevik Revolution.The businesswoman, Elena Baturina, and five other Russian-speakers were on board the twin-engine Bombardier Challenger 601 that crashed into a field shortly after departing from an airport near the city of Darmstadt on its way to the Spanish island of Majorca, the local police said. All seven passengers and the pilot, the son of the owner of the aircraft, were killed.The plane took off from Hahn Airport, and the pilots began their descent onto an airport in the German town of Zweibrücken, on the Rhine River, at around 5 p.m. local time. The crash occurred a few minutes later, at a height of just 100 feet, according to a preliminary investigation by the local police.Ms. Baturina, a former beauty pageant winner from the city of Ryazan, was part of a business group that built a banking empire that stretched across Russia, into the Baltics and into other former Soviet bloc countries.Her holdings included the oil company Lukoil and the airline Aeroflot. She owned a 50 percent share in the Bank of Cyprus, now one of the largest lenders on the island of Cyprus, which was forced to seek help in 2013 after a banking crisis.

Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi will visit Washington next month for the first time since taking office in 2014, the Trump administration announced Thursday.White House press secretary Sean Spicer said el-Sissi's Feb. 8 visit would focus on "economic and counter-terrorism efforts." He also said Egypt and the United States are working together on "co-production" of a Hollywood film that highlights how Egypt helped rescue Jews from Nazi Germany. Spicer said he believed the film would "showcase the very strong relationship and co-operation that we have with Egypt."There was no immediate comment from Egyptian officials.Relations have been strained since former President Barack Obama and el-Sissi's predecessor, Islamist Mohammed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, exchanged harsh words.

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Thursday that the number of sexual harassment complaints workers filed with the agency over the past year rose for the first time in nearly a decade. It attributed the increase to the #MeToo movement.The commission said the number of complaints, known as charges, filed in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 rose more than 12 percent over the previous year, when it received about 6,700. It said the numbers were preliminary, as the agency typically publishes comprehensive data from its fiscal year by the following February.EEOC Acting Chair Victoria Lipnic said in a statement that the numbers reflected "the heightened demand of the #MeToo movement."The #MeToo movement emerged in response to accusations of sexual harassment and abuse by powerful men in the entertainment industry starting last October. Many lawyers and other experts had predicted that the movement would spur an uptick in harassment claims.The number of sexual harassment charges lodged with the EEOC had fallen each year since 2010, when nearly 8,000 were filed.Many worker advocates and women's rights groups, as well as the commission in a 2016 report, said the decline was most likely the result of victims' decisions not to report harassment, rather than employers' efforts to effectively address it.In order to sue employers for harassment, workers must first file charges with the EEOC, which enforces federal laws banning workplace discrimination based on sex and other factors.

MANILA, PHILIPPINES - Filipino fans remembering boxing legend Muhammad Ali gathered near the site of his epic "Thrilla in Manila" fight with Joe Frazier for an art and photo tribute Friday.The display near Araneta Coliseum at Ali Mall was launched hours before Ali's burial in the United States. Ali died June 3 at age 74.Outside the coliseum, a cutout picture of Ali stands in a boxing ring. Fans crowded around a screen playing videos of the 1975 match that put the Philippines on the map. At the mall, memorabilia including boxing gloves with Ali's autograph, an original souvenir program and a gold commemorative coin also are on display.The Oct. 1, 1975, heavyweight championship, one of the greatest boxing matches in history, was won by Ali on a technical knockout at the jam-packed coliseum in Manila's suburban Quezon city and was watched by a worldwide audience.Filipino fans look at the memorabilia of the Oct. 1, 1975 "Thrilla in Manila" World Heavyweight boxing fight between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier at the launch of an exhibit at The Ali Mall in suburban Quezon city northeast of Manila, Philippines Friday, June 10, 2016.Some facts about the fight:— It was the third fight between Ali and Frazier, his most bitter rival. The boxers had split the first two bouts, neither of which compared to the grueling rubber match.

ORLANDO, Fla. (AP) — With a tight job market making it more difficult to hire, The Walt Disney Co. said Thursday it's offering to pay the full four-year tuition for hourly workers who want to earn a college degree.Disney, the country's second-largest employer, said the program will begin in January at its Walt Disney World resort in Florida and expand to the Disneyland Resort in California in 2022.Disney is partnering with Guild Education, which offers programs where companies pay the tuition for workers.Disney said it'll have no more than 250 participants in the first year, but hopes to expand the program into the thousands in the future. Workers who get accepted into the program will be able to use up to 85 hours of paid time off per year for their classes.

Text sizeIn the coming months, the United States is poised to become the world's largest producer of oil. Vietnam, a nation of more than 100 million people, is preparing to become one of the world's largest oil consumers.The economic logic for the nation's burgeoning relationship with the petroleum industry is fairly straightforward.Vietnam's economy grew at an annual rate of 6.8% in the first quarter, its third straight quarter of robust growth, and there are few signs that the momentum is abating. The nation is enjoying a strong rebound in its trade with the United States, its largest export market, and the IMF predicts that growth in the nation will average 5.8% through 2019. The Asian Development Bank expects growth to hit 6.3% this year and 6.5% next year.The nation's trade surplus with the U.S. reached $17.7 billion last year, up nearly 80% from 2015. Vietnam's foreign-exchange reserves are near a record $70 billion. "The Vietnamese economy has strong fundamentals and is in the right place at the right time, so to speak," says Pham Chi Lan, the head of the Institute of Economics and Policy at the Foreign Trade University in Ho Chi Minh City.The Vietnamese government is also pursuing a goal to become an industrialized economy by 2035.Newsletter Sign-upVietnam has a long history of trade with the U.S. Vietnam became the first noncommunist nation to establish relations with Washington in the post-World War II era in 1954. Its trade relationship with the U.S. has grown ever since, but only in recent years has that trade become increasingly linked to American energy supplies. That relationship, which was once seen as purely economic, has taken a geopolitical turn amid an escalating trade war between China and the U.S.U.S. energy companies have poured billions of dollars into the Vietnamese energy sector over the last few years. Exxon Mobil has made a string of large investments to develop oil and gas fields in the South China Sea.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. - A North Carolina college student slain while confronting a gunman in his classroom was expected to receive a hero's send-off Thursday as his body is taken back to his hometown with a police escort.Riley Howell's body was scheduled to depart from a Charlotte funeral home Thursday morning en route to Waynesville in the western part of the state.Meanwhile, the suspect accused of killing Howell and another student at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte, while wounding four others, was due to appear in the afternoon to face charges including murder and attempted murder.Howell died in his classroom Tuesday, charging and tackling the suspect who opened fire with a legally obtained pistol, authorities said.Howell's decision to fight for the lives of others fit his character, said his friend David Belnap, who attended a candlelight vigil Wednesday with a homemade T-shirt with “Riley Howell is a hero” written on the back.“It seems very much like something he would do. I want that to be his legacy, that he lost his life to protect those he cared about,” the sophomore said about his friend.Howell, 21, likely went through the same active shooter drills as countless other students of his generation.

A top United Nations official says drug traffickers are using a more sophisticated system to smuggle drugs from West Africa to Europe.Alexander Schmidt, the West African head of the U.N. Office on Drug Crime, says the amount of cocaine seized in western Africa has gone down, suggesting that smugglers are repositioning drug routes and becoming increasingly sophisticated at hiding their operations.Schmidt says officials also believe cartels are using lightweight submarines similar to ones seen off the South American and the Caribbean coasts.Schmidt says although a few Latin Americans still dominate the trade, West Africans are starting to have increasingly influential roles.He places the value of the drugs passing through West Africa at $800 million.Schmidt spoke Monday at a meeting of the policy committee of the West Africa Coast Initiative.

A new collection of short stories written in Tigrigna was recently published in Ethiopia. The author, Yared Tesfay, is a writer living in the town of Mekele, capital of the Tigray region of Ethiopia. The stories in this collection, which features five male narrators, span the years 1978 to 2003, a period marked by the civil war in Ethiopia.While reading the story “Yiben” the reader witnesses the political and social turbulence in Ethiopia between 1974 and 1977 through the eyes of the narrator, Tarekegn Bichara, a young university student. Another story, “Rer Giyamma,” focuses on the struggle of two young people, the narrator and his cousin, against a tyrant.

SANTIAGO - The Chilean public prosecutor's office has summoned the archbishop of Santiago to testify in an investigation into the alleged cover-up of child sexual abuse by members of the Catholic Church, the archbishopric said on Tuesday. The Santiago archbishopric said in a statement that Ricardo Ezzati had been summoned to speak with prosecutors on August 21 as a defendant accused of concealment. Prosecutors investigating criminal accusations against bishops, clerics and lay workers in the Roman Catholic Church in Chile are also probing claims that Ezzati and others covered up a network of 14 priests who systematically abused minors. Ezzati denied wrongdoing and vowed to cooperate with authorities. "I reiterate my commitment and the commitment of Santiago's Church to the victims," Ezzati said in the statement by his office. "I have the conviction that I never covered up or obstructed justice, and as a citizen will fulfill my duty to contribute all the information that may help clarify the facts." Last month police seized documents from the ecclesiastical court of the diocese of Santiago. The child sex abuse crisis has gripped Chile's Catholic Church since 2011, when Chilean priest Fernando Karadima was found guilty by the Vatican of abusing children in the 1970s and 1980s. Juan Carlos Cruz, one of Karadima's victims, said on Twitter that Ezzati has "little time left as archbishop of Santiago, but his new mission of answering for his cover-up, lies and other crimes ... has just begun."

LONDON - Details emerged Tuesday of the three London Bridge attackers: a Pakistan-born failed customer service clerk with links to one of Europe's most prolific hate preachers, a Moroccan pastry chef whose partner said he once went swimming rather than see his daughter and an Italian national who told authorities he "wanted to be a terrorist."At least two of the men were known to British intelligence and law enforcement officials, raising questions about whether anything could have been done to stop the attack, which began Saturday when the men drove a rented van into a crowd and then leaped out to stab people who crossed their paths. Seven were killed and nearly 50 wounded. All three of the attackers were shot dead by police.British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was fair to ask how the attackers "slipped through our net."Security has become a key issue in the run-up to Thursday's general election. British security officials said none of the men was considered violent, but they acknowledged the difficulty of predicting whether extremists will turn dangerous. The assault was the third attack in three months in which most of the assailants had been on authorities' radar at some point.As the investigation expanded to look at how the men knew one another and whether they were part of a larger conspiracy, Pakistani intelligence authorities swooped Tuesday into the town of Jhelum, where Khurum Butt lived until the time he was 7, when he moved to Britain. His cousin, 18-year-old Bilal Dar, told The Associated Press that Butt's uncle was taken in for questioning. It was unclear if he was detained."Our family is hurt by what he did," Dar said in the town about two hours east of Pakistan's capital.

for ChangeIraqi expatriates from London cast their votes in the country's general elections, expressing hopes for a brighter future after decades of war and sectarian division. They also reflected on the challenges facing Iraqi voters as the polls opened Saturday.

A polling booth in North Korea. (Photo : File)North Koreans head to the polls Friday to choose the members of the country's 13th Supreme People's Assembly (SPA).The SPA is the only institution in North Korea that has the supreme authority to adopt legislation and exercise administrative control, according to the North Korean Central News Agency.With all the 589 members of the SPA, all serving terms of up to five years, seeking re-election, the SPA will be expanded to 697 members.With the North's Constitution stating that every five years there should be a national general election and a SPA election, the SPA election also serves as a general election.The North's Constitution also calls for the SPA election to be held at the "first available opportunity" after five years. That means a SPA election should be held about a year before the end of an SPA's five-year term.The constitution says that all voters should be over 20 and residents of the nation's capital city, Pyongyang.Although they are only the electoral blocs that represent the entire party, the two biggest blocs are referred to as the Kimilsungist-Kimjongilist and Chondongjin-chongu, or Chollima-Unhasu in Korean.The Kimilsungist-Kimjongilist bloc includes the Workers' Party of Korea and the Korean People's Army. The Chollima-Unhasu bloc, meanwhile, was created from the merger of the ruling Workers' Party of Korea, the Chondoist Chongu Party and others.Voters in this election, however, are choosing the members of the SPA based on their party affiliations rather than their individual candidates. The ballots in the election list the names of the parties first and the candidate second.
is a TV program aired by South African national television news channel eNCA.

http://www.voanews.com/enCopyright 20162015-08-02T15:50:23+00:00http://www.voanews.com/media/voice-of-america/assets/feeds/logos/logo.pnghttp://www.voanews.com/U.S. Military Warns of ‘Unintended Consequences’ of Pullout from Afghanistanhttp://www.voanews.com/a/u-s-military-warns-of-unintended-consequences-of-pullout-from-afghanistan/3650779.htmlhttp://www.voanews.com/a/u-s-military-warns-of-unintended-consequences-of-pullout-from-afghanistan/3650779.htmlUS military leaders have admitted that an early withdrawal from Afghanistan could have dangerous repercussions in the region.

Myanmar has established a commission of inquiry to probe allegations of human rights abuses in conflict-torn Rakhine state, authorities said Monday, as the country faces growing calls for accountability over accusations of ethnic cleansing against Rohingya Muslims.The four-person commission will be comprised of two local and two international members — Filipino diplomat Rosario Manalo and Kenzo Oshima, Japan's former ambassador to the U.N. — the Myanmar President's Office said in a statement. Manalo, 82, a former undersecretary of foreign affairs, will chair the commission.The two local members are lawyer Mya Thein and Aung Tun Thet, an economist and former UN official. Aung Tun Thet was last year appointed by de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi to a key role in Myanmar's response to the Rakhine crisis, and in April told a Bangladesh newspaper that Myanmar had "no intention of ethnic cleansing.""

MADRID - Spain heads to the polls Sunday for its most divisive and open-ended election in decades, set to result in a fragmented parliament in which the far-right will get a sizeable presence for the first time since the country’s return to democracy.After a tense campaign dominated by emotive issues, notably national identity and gender equality, the likelihood that any coalition deal will take weeks or months to be brokered will feed into a broader mood of political uncertainty across Europe.At least five parties from across the political spectrum have a chance of being in government and they could struggle to agree on a deal between them, meaning a repeat election is one of several possible outcomes.A few things are clear, however, based on opinion polls and conversations with party insiders. No single party will get a majority; the Socialist party of outgoing Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez is leading the race; and there will be lawmakers from the far-right Vox party.Beyond that, the result is too close to call.Spanish Prime Minister and Socialist Party candidate Pedro Sanchez, center, smiles for a photo during an election campaign event in Toledo, central Spain, April 26, 2019. What undecided voters do in this tight race will shape the fortunes of the two political blocs that loosely took shape during campaigning that ended Friday.?

With Coronavirus CareBritain's Prince Charles opened London's newest hospital on Friday, a temporary facility that will provide thousands of extra beds and hundreds of extra staff to help the capital cope with the coronavirus outbreak.Charles, the 71-year-old heir to the British throne, opened the 4,000-bed NHS Nightingale Hospital at a temporary venue attached to one of London's biggest hospitals.Charles said he was "enormously touched" to be asked to open the hospital, a statement from his Clarence House office said."It is without doubt a spectacular and almost unbelievable feat of work in every sense," said Charles, who completed the opening via video link from his Scottish home Birkhall, the Daily Mail newspaper said.The temporary facility at the ExCeL exhibition center in east London will initially provide up to 500 beds equipped with ventilators and oxygen, with the possibility of expanding to almost 4,000, the Ministry of Defense said.Charles was a candidate for coronavirus testing earlier this month but was later found to be negative."In these troubled times with this invisible killer stalking the whole world, the fact in this country we have the NHS is even more valuable that before," Charles said, adding his thanks to all those involved in its "spectacular and almost unbelievable" construction in just nine days.On Saturday, the Nightingale hospital will receive its first patients, some of whom will have contracted the COVID-19 disease. They include British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who has been in self-isolation after testing positive for the virus.After initially being treated in hospital, Johnson, 55, was taken to intensive care on Monday where he spent three nights receiving oxygen support. On Thursday he was moved back to a normal ward and was speaking on the telephone to U.S. President Donald Trump, who was giving updates on his condition.Earlier on Friday, Queen Elizabeth II sent a message to those working on the hospital, which will provide critical care for the most critically ill."

in May: SpokespersonGENEVA, Switzerland - U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights Michelle Bachelet is planning to visit Venezuela next month as part of her efforts to push for improvements in human rights, including freedom of expression, the United Nations' human rights office said on Thursday.Bachelet is expected to meet government officials and civil society representatives during her trip to Caracas, in what her spokesman Rupert Colville described as an "ongoing dialogue" with the government of President Nicolas Maduro."It is a fact that it is very, very difficult to access the country and we have many requests for a visit from NGOs, from members of the National Assembly, from members of the government and from international organizations," Colville told a Geneva news briefing."It's something that we have under active consideration and we'll be making an announcement about quite soon."FILE - People take part in a protest over shortages of medicines and medical supplies in Caracas, Venezuela, April 30, 2019.Bachelet has been in dialogue with the government since her appointment to the position in 2014, the year after Maduro's predecessor Hugo Chavez died and was succeeded by his political protege.The United Nations is one of the few international actors with direct access to Venezuela. Bachelet's predecessor Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein visited the country several times."

by HomosexualsLOS ANGELES, Calif. — The American homosexual community has declared that the new blood screening and deferral policy released by the Food and Drug Administration on May 15 is an unfair targeting of its members, who have donated billions of dollars' worth of blood to the Red Cross.The new FDA policy was issued in response to the recent cases of HIV contamination of blood products, and calls on blood banks to eliminate all donors who have engaged in activities that might increase the risk of HIV infection in the last year, including all homosexuals."We're shocked and disgusted by the new FDA policy," said Jim Moulton, a prominent gay rights activist from San Francisco. "It is a gross violation of gay rights. There is no scientific rationale for excluding gay men from donating blood just because we engage in behavior that increases our likelihood of contracting AIDS."Many gay activists are now calling for the FDA to be stripped of its authority to regulate blood donations, saying the federal agency has no scientific or ethical rationale for targeting gay men with a deferrral."All gay men should demand the right to donate blood," said John Bosworth, spokesperson for the national homosexual movement. "FDA officials are a bunch of homophobes. They are afraid of being labeled 'homosexual activists' for allowing gay men to donate blood. This is the kind of discrimination we have fought against for decades.""In this case, if FDA officials allow gay men to donate blood, they will be branded 'gay activists,'" added Bosworth. "If they don't, they will be branded 'homophobes.' Either way, they become enemies of our movement."The issue is not whether gay men can donate blood but rather who the FDA will allow to donate blood. It is a matter of who the FDA considers to be a "homosexual activist."

Once again, thunderstorms have forced a delay for the launch of the U.S. space shuttle Endeavour.It is the second evening in a row that NASA has canceled the liftoff due to weather. The latest postponement Monday comes after two abortive attempts last month because of hydrogen fuel leaks.The space agency has until Tuesday or Wednesday to get Endeavour into orbit and up to the International Space Station. Otherwise, flight managers have to wait until near the end of July to make way for a Russian supply ship to launch and dock at the station.The seven-member shuttle crew plans to conduct a two-week mission to deliver the final piece of a Japanese laboratory known as Kibo. Kibo means "hope" in Japanese.Kibo amounts to a porch to be installed on the space station. It is designed to expose experiments to the vacuum of space.Endeavour will carry astronaut Timothy Kopra to take the place of Japan's Koichi Wakata, who has been on the space station since March.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. (AP) — As Republicans choose their nominees in dozens of U.S. House primaries across eight states, some establishment-aligned party figures are worried that a surge in conservative firebrands could cost the GOP seats in the general election — and perhaps control of the chamber after November.Primary season can be a precarious time for any political party as factions seek to move it in their direction. But the anxieties are particularly acute within the GOP this year as the party struggles to unify behind a unifying standard-bearer and faces a daunting electoral environment this fall.The Republican candidates running this year are overwhelmingly to the right of their predecessors, an assessment that extends even to traditionally conservative districts. In Missouri’s U.S. Senate contest, the GOP field is filled with candidates who have challenged or opposed mask mandates and are strongly backing former President Donald Trump’s false claims of election fraud.“There is a bit of danger in the extreme positions being taken,” said former Sen. John Danforth, who served three decades ago as the party’s nominee. “There’s a danger that we could lose control of the Senate and lose seats in the House if we go too far, too fast.”If control of the Senate hangs in the balance this year, the GOP’s conservative wing is giving moderates every reason to shy away from open seats this fall.In Texas, Air Force veteran MJ Hegar is the best funded of seven Democrats running for Senate. But she’s being challenged from the right by Republican State Sen. Don Huffines.In Arizona, Democrats have their most crowded primary field in a decade, including several candidates who have backed Medicare for All. That’s prompted criticism from one of the party’s most powerful Senate weapons, Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, who has warned against abandoning the party’s center-left flank.In Alabama, Mo Brooks is so far ahead of the five Republicans running to replace retiring GOP Rep. Mo Brooks.

ISLAMABAD - A suicide bomber targeted a crowd of Afghan Sikhs and Hindus on Thursday, killing at least 19 people and injuring seven others during a religious celebration in the eastern city of Jalalabad."The suicide attacker detonated the bomb as people were leaving a shrine after their prayers. It's a gurdwara," Nangarhar provincial governor's spokesman Attaullah Khogyani said.Hinduism is the third-largest religion in Afghanistan. Sikhs, mainly from the tiny minority of India's Hindu community, make up a much smaller minority.Khogyani added that six of the 19 people killed had been identified and that some of the bodies were badly dismembered.No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attack. But militant group Islamic State, which is led in Afghanistan by local affiliate Islamic State in Khorasan Province, has carried out a number of attacks on Sikhs and Hindus in Afghanistan in recent years.Jalalabad is the capital of Nangarhar province. Khogyani said the attack took place on the third day of the country's commemoration of the Sikh festival of Guru Nanak's birth, which is widely celebrated by the Afghan Sikh minority.The U.S. military has said there are fewer than 1,000 American troops in Afghanistan as part of the NATO-led Resolute Support mission. Most of the U.S. military personnel left the country in July ahead of the final withdrawal of American forces.There are still an estimated 5,000 troops and contractors operating in the country, but only to provide security for diplomatic personnel and the ongoing military operations.The United States and the Taliban signed an agreement in February, which stipulated that all foreign troops would leave Afghanistan by mid-2021 if the militant group fulfills its commitments. One of those commitments is an intra-Afghan dialogue aimed at ending decades of hostilities between the militant group and Afghan government.

Disgraced Italian football club Juventus is appealing its punishment for match fixing to a civil court, and risks further sanctions from the Italian federation and the world governing body, FIFA.The Turin-based club was stripped of its last two Serie A titles, relegated to the second division, and docked 17 points for its part in a match fixing scandal.Juventus said the penalty was too severe and started the appeal process before the Lazio regional court near Rome. A Juventus spokesman said Thursday's action merely notified the court of the club's intention to appeal but is not the official documentation. A hearing is scheduled for September 6.The Italian Football Federation has threatened further sanctions for taking the matter to civil court, including deducting another three points.The Italian governing body acted after FIFA threatened to bar all Italian teams - including clubs and the World Cup-winning national team - from international competition.

And that is why we need to have good radios.When you go outside, you can have fun without WiFi or even cell phones (depending on the area), you can communicate with people over long distance without getting any charges, you can tune in and listen to someone without knowing anything about them. All of that on just regular radio signals.It is a very different experience. It is very intimate and it is a very good way to stay in contact with other people, like family members, in case of a natural disaster or a bad time at work.We should preserve this technology, not let it die along with AM and FM, for example. We should preserve it and we should have many many more radios of all kinds.I live in an area of southern Ontario where most of the land mass is covered by trees. Most of the time this is nice, but there are times when I want to be able to receive radio transmissions, and when I do, it's almost always CB radio. I really wish that there were CB repeaters here, especially for the HF band (144-148 Mhz).What's the advantage of a repeater over just using a very long wire antenna?Repeaters work well to transmit, but only at the expense of reception quality (they add noise to the airwaves).For a long distance (20-40+ miles) I would think that a wire antenna on a high tower would be best.Not really. You can make a very decent HF wire with about $15 of wire and a $20 counterpoise.

KAFR KANDIL, Egypt - Official results from Egypt's historic presidential election are not expected until next week, but early speculation after the first two-day round is showing a race too close to call. The rural vote appears as divided as it is elsewhere.As Egyptians await the results of their first truly open presidential election, fault lines between Islamists and old guard secularists appear to cut across the nation. In the village of Kafr Kandil, south of Cairo, the choice plays well with the largely conservative rural vote: some seek stability in religion, others in past performance. Many of the latter look to veteran diplomat Amr Moussa, who along with former Air Force chief Ahmed Shafik, promises a return to pre-uprising law and order, minus the corruption. Outside the village school, which is serving as the village polling station, Shadia Ewis, a housewife and mother of five, hopes Moussa wins. She thinks he's a "respectable man" who "could control the country." Her friend and fellow housewife, Magda Hassan, agrees. She says she wants Moussa to institute reforms, so that it won't be like it was under the old government, when everything was exploited. Getting a fair shake from the government is a key concern of Islamist candidates' supporters, too. Farmer Ali Hassan Abdel Baki believes the best man for the job is the Muslim Brotherhood's Mohamed Morsi. Sitting in the bright sunshine, his fields of tomatoes and grains behind him, Abdel Baki says "there is unfinished business." He says a lot of people are out of work, and the next leader, "with God's help, will look after the poor."

JOHANNESBURG - As South Africa joins the rest of the world in commemorating World AIDS Day, experts say the country's women below age 25 have a high HIV infection rate and studies show they are getting the virus from older men.Lolobrigitha Tsupa, 30, was 23 when she learned she was HIV positive. She was looking for a man who could satisfy her craving for a fast and high-flying life. But Tsupa said she got more than that. "I met this man who had money, drove nice cars, and the man was very old, old enough to be my father. He would buy me things, gifts, and he would take me out," she said. "That is the life I wanted to live and I did not have that at home. Anyway, that is where I got the virus from."Tsupa’s story is similar to that of 28-year-old Brenda Masango. Masango said she discovered she was HIV positive in 2007, while still a student at the University of Tswane. She said it all started when her parents cut their financial support to punish her bad behavior. "I had to buy clothes for myself" and cover food costs at school, she said.

Ahead of National ConventionWASHINGTON (AP) — Republicans will try to pull the party together this week during the national convention, but the effort is likely to sputter as President Donald Trump continues his efforts to undermine the election results.Trump’s refusal to agree to a peaceful transfer of power if he loses is another major obstacle, even as he has been promising for weeks to deliver a prime-time convention address making the case for his reelection.GOP Chair Ronna McDaniel said in an interview that the president is planning to deliver an upbeat speech that will focus on what she says is the strongest economy in modern history. She said he's expected to focus on what he's done to lower drug prices, how the economy has fared during the coronavirus and how he has strengthened U.S. military.The party will make the case that a second Trump term will be good for the middle class, and McDaniel predicted in an interview that he would win back the handful of battleground states he lost in 2016 to Democrat Hillary Clinton. But that campaign is already hitting roadblocks.Trump is mired in a recession, the coronavirus continues to ravage several states and the national death toll from the virus is nearing 180,000.With the general election less than seven months away, more than half of the nation believes the country is heading in the wrong direction under his guidance.Democrats have been casting about for a unifying message that can capture a broad array of voters, and so far they are decidedly mixed on their approach.Joe Biden, the Democratic presidential nominee, has focused his campaign on Trump's failures in dealing with the pandemic, an economy that has struggled to return to normal and enduring racial inequalities.But Biden has shied away from some progressive goals, particularly the most liberal of calls to overhaul policing, which are deeply unpopular with most Black voters, and some young voters. Biden has also stayed away from the Medicare for All proposal endorsed by Vermont Sen.

Eleven people, including several journalists, have been killed in a brutal attack on a convoy of vehicles near the town of Raga in Western Bahr el Ghazal state in South Sudan, officials said Monday.Western Bahr el Ghazal Governor Rizik Zachariah Hassan called for flags to be flown at half-staff around the state for three days. He expressed his condolences to the families of the dead and vowed the state government will not stop working because of the attack.Newly appointed Raga County Commissioner Maradom James was among the four people wounded in the attack on Sunday.We were not expecting to survive... So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs.James' private secretary, Justin Abo Saleh, who was in the same car as the county commissioner, said the assault came out of the blue and was ferocious. He said the two vehicles came under a hail of bullets from both sides of the road.“We were not expecting to survive," he said. "We talked to our driver that he should not stop and already these people started firing on us. So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs."The car that Saleh and James were in was able to get away. After awhile, they returned to where the brutal assault had taken place and found a gruesome scene.The victims had been shot and then hacked to pieces before their bodies were set alight, Saleh said.

Dr. Greg Mills, National Director of the South African Institute of International Affairs, says the Middle East crisis has a great deal of relevance to South Africa and the rest of the continent. He says South Africa has Muslim and Jewish populations, while many other African countries have large Muslim populations, such as Nigeria and Sudan.He says Africa has an interest in the Middle East partly due to its own colonial past and developmental challenges. The crisis does, however, divert attention away from Africa.He says some African leaders could contribute to the Middle East peace process, such as Nelson Mandela. But he says those leaders are currently busy trying to bring peace in such places as Burundi, Angola and the DRC.He says the historical experience of Africa, especially South Africa, has lessons to offer to Israel and the Palestinians. Dr. Mills says there?

This morning, the Washington Post published an opinion piece by the Democratic presidential candidate with the headline "Bernie Sanders’s Democratic socialist agenda is what America needs."Sanders was the only member of the US Senate to vote against the $300 billion defense bill in 2018. He has introduced a bill that would bar the federal government from spending money on private detention facilities. He has introduced legislation that would prohibit the Pentagon from conducting a war with Iran without the express permission of Congress.Sanders, who has been a senator for Vermont since 2007 and ran for president as a Democrat in 2016, has been a consistent critic of US military adventurism overseas and has called for greater spending on education, health care, infrastructure, and housing. He has also called for greater investment in American renewable energy, a move that he believes will create millions of jobs and provide a major boost to the US economy.He has also backed the Green New Deal, the ambitious and unprecedented 10-year climate change initiative pushed by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Sen. Ed Markey.He is running as a progressive who can help deliver what the Democratic base wants — Medicare for all, a Green New Deal, tuition-free college, and higher taxes on the wealthy. It will be interesting to see how his campaign does and whether other progressive candidates jump on the Sanders bandwagon.At the same time, however, Sanders is also trying to differentiate himself from Ocasio-Cortez, whose meteoric rise as a leading voice of the Democratic Party’s progressive wing has made her a target of right-wing attacks."I am a proud Democratic-socialist," he declared in a video announcing his presidential run on February 19. "I consider myself — and what we are running — to be a political movement. And we are putting together an unprecedented, multigenerational, multi-racial movement."

: CBPThe number of unaccompanied children detained at the border by US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) last month surged to an all-time high of just over 4,000, according to the agency's data.The number of unaccompanied minors in the care of the CBP also saw a significant increase over July, rising by 9% to a record number of over 3,200.Additionally, CBP data released on Wednesday revealed that there was an additional increase in the number of family units detained at the border, rising by 2% to over 8,500 people.According to the agency's data, CBP had an 80% average daily rate of apprehending unaccompanied minors in August, with 4,177 minors encountered.The number of unaccompanied minors in CBP custody dropped by 3% on August 31, but only slightly, ending the month with 3,234 minors in its care.The surge in the number of unaccompanied minors and families arriving at the border comes as the Biden administration works to process thousands of migrants held in CBP custody.More than 4,000 unaccompanied migrant children and teens were being held in CBP custody on August 31, according to the agency's data. The CBP's Rio Grande Valley Sector, which includes the cities of McAllen, Brownsville, and Hidalgo, Texas, reported the greatest number of unaccompanied minors, with approximately 1,100 being held in custody on Wednesday.In total, there were 21,074 migrants in CBP custody as of August 31, according to the agency's data.Despite an increase in arrests of people attempting to cross the southwest border, the Biden administration has continued to insist that its policies are not responsible for the surge.According to the latest statistics from Customs and Border Protection (CBP), border agents had stopped over 212,000 migrants attempting to cross the southwest border in August.The Biden administration has come under fire from Republicans for its handling of the border crisis, particularly with regard to its refusal to reinstate Trump-era policies such as the Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP), which forced individuals seeking asylum to remain in Mexico during the course of their immigration proceedings."

(AP) – The U.S. Supreme Court has told a Kansas court to reopen its consideration of the case of a former math teacher who came to the U.S. illegally from Mexico as a child but avoided deportation during the Obama administration.Sergio Garcia, a 35-year-old native of Mexico, has been teaching at a high school in suburban Kansas City.But the district fired him in 2013 over his arrest in 2011 when he was accused of running a red light and was found to have a fictitious driver’s license. The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency began deportation proceedings against him but then closed the case because it found he would be eligible for legal residency under an Obama administration program for people brought to the United States as children.Garcia successfully defended himself against a deportation order after the federal government reopened his case, but the Kansas Board of Education revoked his teaching license in 2018, citing the traffic violations.

Iran has filed a lawsuit against the United States alleging that Washington's decision in May to impose sanctions after pulling out of a nuclear deal violates a 1955 treaty between the two countries, the International Court of Justice said Tuesday.A State Department official said the application was without merit and the United States would fight it in the court."While we cannot comment on the specifics, Iran's application is baseless and we intend to vigorously defend the United States before the ICJ," a State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters.President Donald Trump withdrew the United States from the 2015 nuclear pact with Iran reached by his predecessor Barack Obama and other world powers, and ordered tough U.S. sanctions on Tehran. Under the 2015 deal, which Trump sees as flawed, Iran reined in its disputed nuclear program under U.N. monitoring and won a removal of international sanctions in return.The ICJ, which is based in The Hague and is also known as the World Court, is the United Nations tribunal for resolving international disputes. Iran's filing asks the ICJ to order the United States to provisionally lift its sanctions ahead of more detailed arguments."

GENEVA - A new report by the Inter-Parliamentary Union finds that worldwide, members of parliament in Africa and Asia are at greater risk of intimidation, imprisonment, and other abuse than in other regions.The report says members of parliament are subject to multiple abuses, including death, torture, threats, arbitrary arrest and detention. The Inter-Parliamentary Union says its Committee on the Human Rights of Parliamentarians is investigating the cases of 311 MPs from 41 countries - a 13 percent increase over 2013.The data reveal 38 percent of the MPs who faced governmental abuse are from Africa, 25 percent from Asia, 18 percent from the Middle East and North Africa, 14 percent from the Americas and five percent from Europe.IPU human rights program manager Rogier Huizenga said the three worst cases in Africa were Democratic Republic of Congo, Zambia and Eritrea. They represent 21.5 percent of abuse cases on the continent.“DRC - there are a number of serious cases where due process is a concern, where freedom of expression is a concern. Eritrea is the famous case of the G-11, the members of parliament who wrote a critical letter to the authorities, to the president, Afwerki, 2001, and were taken away in September that year and were never seen again. And, then the case in Zambia where there are concerns about the use of the Public Order Act and the limitations that that brings along for the right to freedom of assembly,” said Huizenga.In Asia, the IPU cites 78 MPs from 12 countries who are under threat.It singles out the Maldives as the worst violator.

at October MeetingPosted: Fri 7:48 AM, Oct 20, 2006&nbsp|&nbspUpdated: Fri 9:01 AM, Oct 20, 2006Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said Thursday that investors appear to be increasingly willing to risk higher U.S. interest rates, but he did not signal whether a policy change is imminent.Greenspan, appearing before the House Banking Committee, said it appears global economic worries have subsided since the spring, when market turmoil pushed the Fed to lower its target interest rate for the first time in 10 years."It appears that financial markets are now more able to accept the idea of higher rates," he said.The Fed left its key federal funds rate in a range between 2.25 percent and 2.5 percent last month. Fed officials next meet Oct. 24-25.Investors will closely follow Greenspan's testimony before the Senate Banking Committee Thursday as well. He's scheduled to appear before the House committee again Tuesday.Analysts have grown more confident in the past few weeks that the Fed may consider another rate cut by the end of the year.The market's current expectations are a rate hike at the end of the year and a Fed policy meeting on Dec. 13. The Fed is expected to hold off rate increases until January.Greenspan's testimony Thursday on Capitol Hill was part of a new arrangement that replaces the Fed chairman's regular twice-a-year appearances before Congress.

The news broke on the day GM had planned to announce details of its financial results for the fourth quarter, scheduled for this Wednesday, January 26.But the company did announce an agreement with the UAW. Under this deal, the company agreed to invest $1.3 billion in U.S. plants, and created thousands of jobs during the next year.This is a very good development, and GM stock rallied on Monday, and again on Tuesday.GM stock rallied after the UAW announced a deal, but... [+] it is not enough to bring GM back to life. (Photo by David Becker/Getty Images) 2016 Getty Images">Today, General Motors (GM) announced it will idle five plants in the U.S., as part of a major restructuring. While the company will shut down three plants that make large trucks, it is also axing two factories that make cars. In addition, the company will make some production cuts.Investors cheered the news, and GM stock jumped more than 5% in pre-market trading. This is good news for investors, and I think it is great that GM can now plan ahead.It is an especially big deal in terms of financial results, too, as CEO Mary Barra will no longer have to worry about keeping these plants open.She must have been in quite a bind, running a company that builds cars in the U.S., that could not sell them in the U.S. It is not easy running a business when you are forced to manufacture products in the U.S. that nobody wants to buy in the U.S.But now, GM has an answer. It will invest in making cars, with a focus on electric vehicles. In an interesting twist, GM said it would close the two car factories, while launching an electric car brand.With all this good news, why would GM close five plants? Well, first, let's be clear, this is not good news, per se. This is great news for GM stock owners, as it allows GM to make money again in the U.S.But let's be honest. This is not enough to change GM's fate.

Chinese military vessels are now operating in the Northern Atlantic, and Russian submarines are prowling those same waters at a pace not seen since the end of the Cold War, the Navy’s top admiral told VOA in an exclusive interview.Chief of Naval Operations Adm. John Richardson said China's military movements from the North Atlantic into the Mediterranean Sea create a "new dynamic.""Even five years ago, we wouldn't have seen anything like this,” Richardson said.According to Richardson, the Chinese navy is a global one that is both "ready and capable" of operating wherever Beijing wants.“They're certainly a pacing competition for us in terms of the naval threat,” he told VOA.However, Chinese operations near the United States' eastern shore are not as threatening as Russian vessels lurking below the ocean’s surface. NATO allies from North America to Europe are increasingly concerned about the uptick of Russian submarine activity in the North Atlantic.“We're talking about more (activity) than we've seen in 25 years,” Richardson said.U.S. officials worry that Moscow may try to use its submarines to cut or tap into undersea cables that connect the two continents.Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, speaks to reporters at the Pentagon, July 27, 2018.

TAIPEI - Police clashed with hundreds of protesters in Taipei Monday after the group upset over a trade deal with China broke into the government’s chief office complex. As hundreds more remain camped out in Taiwan’s parliament, the government weighs what to do next. About 2,000 police officers expelled hundreds of protesters from Taiwan’s guarded cabinet offices before dawn on Monday. The government mobilized riot squads and water cannons to oust demonstrators in a five-hour struggle. Protesters want to stop quick approval of the trade deal, calling that approach risky as China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and wants political reunification. Lin Nan-hsin, a 20-year-old protester from a university in central Taiwan, was among those expelled by police. He said there are two camps of protesters, one that advocates peace and the other that prefers a more extreme form of protest as the only way of getting the government’s attention. Lin said that in the end, there was a discussion with the lead protest planners about whether to break into the cabinet complex and finally a go-ahead was given. Taiwan and China signed a service trade pact in June following several other trade and investment agreements reached since 2008.

WASHINGTON — It began as a ragtag group of the disenfranchised taking over a public space.A month later, the Occupy Wall Street movement has lost steam, its members have clashed with police officers in cities across the country, and, at least for now, it's not clear that it's gaining much support.For weeks, its protests, inspired by similar ones in Hong Kong and Madrid, had been drawing hundreds of people each day to New York's financial district and to Zuccotti Park, where activists have pitched tents and where they say they won't leave until they get a meeting with Mayor Michael Bloomberg.Those numbers have dwindled — the biggest group in the park Tuesday was about 200.Demonstrators also took to streets in the District of Columbia on Tuesday. The march wound through Georgetown — in stark contrast to the first two weeks, when the protests were largely in Lower Manhattan — before ending up near the Chinese Embassy.Bloomberg and the protesters are clearly divided on how to resolve their issues, including over what to do with the protesters' tents and tarps and how to handle the police efforts to clear Zuccotti Park. The mayor says he supports the protesters' rights to free speech but not to break laws, such as the city's rules on where protesters can sleep and stay.A Bloomberg adviser said Tuesday that the mayor was open to a meeting with the protesters if they came up with a list of three demands. The adviser spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe the mayor's thinking."What we are trying to do is be a little more respectful and productive," the adviser said.Bloomberg, who attended services at a synagogue Tuesday afternoon, was traveling and unavailable for comment, according to his spokesman.On Monday, Bloomberg urged the protesters to hold a "people's tribunal" that would determine whether officers in the NYPD had acted inappropriately. Bloomberg said he would also ask the city's Department of Investigation to review police actions.Bloomberg, a political independent who has been an at-times vocal supporter of President Barack Obama, has faced criticism from Occupy Wall Street activists who say the mayor doesn't have much connection to the lives of everyday people."

With legislation overhauling taxes and health care on an uncertain path, President Donald Trump returned to the familiar. Trump brought 52 business leaders from New York City to the White House Tuesday to talk about another favorite campaign issue — infrastructure and economic growth. The U.S. economy has so far proven to be a point of pride for a presidency that has otherwise gotten off to a rocky start. Trump inherited a stable economy from former President Barack Obama, an economic recovery that's heading toward its eighth year. But Trump believes he can do more for business. Trump and several of his top aides emphasized plans to cut red tape and jumpstart infrastructure projects at Tuesday's meeting, while also previewing for the CEOs other priorities that include shortening flight times for airplanes, increasing the power grid's efficiency and targeting programs to improve job training. At one point the president had an aide come on stage to hold up a long scroll of the government's approval process for building a highway. The president then pledged to eliminate more than 90 percent of the regulations involved and "still have safety.'' He provided no details. The administration has committed to directing as much as $1 trillion for infrastructure over the next decade, although it has yet to release policy specifics. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao recently said she expects a plan will be unveiled later this year. But getting a measure through Congress could be difficult given the Republican majority in both chambers and their desire to reduce tax rates as much as possible.

ASUNCION - Security forces surrounded Paraguay's Congress on Tuesday while lawmakers argued over a possible change in law that would allow President Horacio Cartes to run for re-election, a move that the opposition says would weaken democratic institutions.A bill allowing presidents to run for a second five-year term was defeated in the legislature last year.This week a group of senators asked for a special session that the opposition interpreted as the start of a new campaign by Cartes and his coalition to enable presidential re-election.Paraguayans taking part in the “Long March” protest, a week-long walk from the interior to the capital, chant slogans against President Horacio Cartes, in Asuncion, Paraguay, Feb. 13, 2017.Opposition leaders and dissident members of Cartes' party accused him of shaking the country's democratic foundations by ordering that Congress be surrounded by police and soldiers.“We have to safeguard the republic,” said Senator Blanca Ovelar, a member of Cartes' Colorado Party who has broken with the president. “This is a situation of institutional breakdown.”Soft drink and tobacco mogul Cartes was elected to a five-year term in 2013. His strongest backers want him to be allowed to run for another term next year. Critics say a constitutional change aimed at benefiting a sitting president would be unfair.The Inter-American Development bank is holding a regional meeting in Asuncion starting on Thursday. Security consultancies International SOS and Control Risks issued a statement warning conference goers to avoid the vicinity of the Congress building in case tensions escalate.On Wednesday, thousands of subsistence farmers are expected to come to capital city Asuncion to lobby for agrarian reform.

Sunday, October 17, 2010New York City's Department of Education is implementing the Common Core Standards--a new set of educational guidelines intended to "raise the bar" for all students, from K-12 through college-level.

In Kenya, sending money home to villages and farms from the city used to be problematic. Many people in rural areas do not have access to banking, making it difficult for them to receive and send money. But a revolutionary mobile telephone system is making it easy to move money, changing Kenyan society. The system was the first of its kind in the world.As Stephen Mbugua works on his farm a half-hour drive from the capital Nairobi, his mobile phone beeps. He is getting a text message saying that his son has sent the elderly farmer some money - through the mobile telephone.Mbugua is a customer of a service called MPESA, offered by a mobile phone company called Safaricom.People who wish to transfer money through their mobile phones can do so at locations across Kenya.And that is good news for Mbugua, who says the service saves him time and money. "I used to go to Nairobi or to any bank to pay my bills. But right now, since MPESA came, I do not go to Nairobi, I just pay my bill from here," he said.Phelister Omari, 22, who works in a hospital in Nairobi, is sending money to her mother. She fills out a form with the amount she wishes to send, plugs that amount into her telephone, and gives the clerk the amount plus extra for charges.People who are sent money go to the agent with their mobile phone, sign a form, and receive the cash.Omari says she appreciates the service. "It is very fast. The MPESA, they are available everywhere.

and More: UN ReportThe Asia-Pacific region is the most exposed in the world to disaster risks due to climate change, and Africa is the region that will suffer the most from the worsening impacts of climate change in coming decades, a United Nations-backed report warned Thursday. The report from the Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters at the Catholic University of Louvain in Belgium said almost 11,000 disasters caused more than $3 billion in losses last year.The region counting the most disaster events was Africa, which had more than 7,000. The report said the number of weather, climate and water extremes that take place each year has doubled since the 1980s.Harsh VardhanUnion Health Minister Dr Harsh Vardhan on Thursday held a virtual meeting with Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of World Health Organisation (WHO), to discuss the roadmap of COVID-19 vaccine rollout in India.Vardhan appreciated the efforts of WHO in coordinating the global response to the pandemic. He stated that the organisation's support at the time of India's need was extremely valuable. He added that the Centre is committed to working together with WHO to strengthen its capacities further.

A Papua New Guinea court has ruled Australia's detention of asylum seekers on its northern island of Manus is illegal.The court said Tuesday the detentions of the asylum seekers violates their constitutional right to personal liberty. It ordered the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea to take immediate steps to end the detention of more than 800 people at the facility.Under Australia's immigration law, anyone intercepted trying to reach its shores by boat is sent for processing to camps in Papua New Guinea and the island nation of Nauru.Australian Immigration Minister Peter Dutton said the ruling would not change Australia's policy of offshore detention. "No one who attempts to travel to Australia illegally by boat will settle in Australia," Dutton said."Those in the Manus Island Regional Processing Center found to be refugees are able to resettle in Papua New Guinea. Those found not to be refugees should return to their country of origin."Detention Camp Sites on Manus Island, Papua New GuineaHuman rights groups have long criticized Australia's asylum seeker policy, which the government says is aimed at protecting its borders and preventing dangerous ocean crossings in unsafe boats."

After Trump Admin Refused to Grant Extensionhttps://www.theepochtimes.com/us-ambassador-to-india-resigns-after-trump-admin-refused-to-grant-extension_3599897.htmlP. Michael McKinley, the U.S. ambassador to India, who has served as the top envoy for less than two years, will be retiring, the State Department announced on Sept. 15.The announcement came only days before the U.S. presidential election in November."Our embassy in New Delhi is stronger than ever, continuing our great partnership with the Indian government and people while furthering U.S. national security, economic, and global priorities during the unprecedented global health crisis," a spokesperson for the department told the Indian Express."Ambassador McKinley has contributed to the advancement of U.S.-India relations for more than three decades, including nearly seven years in this role," the spokesperson added.McKinley's last day in India will be on Oct. 6, though he will continue to serve as a senior adviser, the department said. It wasn't clear whether he would return to the United States immediately or remain in the country for a while."I am grateful to the President and to Secretary Pompeo for the opportunity to serve as the U.S. Ambassador to the Republic of India," McKinley said in a statement on his resignation."I came to India in July of 2017, at the request of President Trump, to reinforce the growing strategic partnership between the world's oldest and largest democracies," he added. "I had thought I would stay in India for two years. But, like others, I was affected by the positive energy of Prime Minister Modi and his vision for a strengthened US-India partnership."McKinley's resignation follows media reports that his application for extension as ambassador was denied by the administration of President Donald Trump.
